channel.title: maGaming RSS Feed - kotaku_com
channel.description: A cleaned-up version of the original gaming feed for kotaku_com

item.title: One Of 2025‚Äôs Coolest-Looking Games Now Has A Demo
item.content:encoded:
Marvel Cosmic Invasion may not have a release date yet, but it does have a demo. The coolest-looking Marvel game in years, and a game many of us at Kotaku are excited to play later this year, now has a small demo up on Steam letting you play the superhero brawler alone or with a few pals.

On October 1, Tribute Games and publisher Dotemu announced and released a free, playable demo for the upcoming Marvel Cosmic Invasion. The demo contains two full levels with boss fights, supports both local and online co-op, and features nine playable characters: Rocket Raccoon, Nova, Phyla-Vell, She-Hulk, Venom, Spider-Man, Wolverine, Storm, and Captain America. Here‚Äôs a new trailer for the demo:

Announced earlier this year during a Nintendo Direct, Marvel Cosmic Invasion is a side-scrolling 2D retro-inspired beat ‚Äôem up being developed by the same studio behind the extremely tubular and awesome TMNT: Shredder‚Äôs Revenge, which was also a 2D co-op brawler. Cosmic Invasion, like Tribute‚Äôs past games, is a snappy and action-packed retro throwback. I played the new demo on Steam for a few minutes and immediately had a blast smashing baddies as She-Hulk and Spider-Man. Swapping between the two, which is this game‚Äôs big gimmick, was great as it let me switch between Spider-Man‚Äôs fast and agile action during some segments and She-Hulk‚Äôs heavy hits during fights with tougher foes. I did encounter some performance dips, which wasn‚Äôt ideal, but hopefully those issues get ironed out when the game launches‚Ä¶eventually.

While there are nine characters in the demo, that‚Äôs not the game‚Äôs full line-up. Marvel Cosmic Invasion is set to include a large roster of 15 characters. We know 12 of the 15 characters that will be playable at launch. Three more have yet to be revealed.

Now the bad news for console players: The new Cosmic Invasion demo isn‚Äôt available on Xbox, PlayStation, or Switch. This has understandably disappointed many players online, with some jumping into the comments of the trailer above to share their frustration.

Regardless, we shouldn‚Äôt have to wait long, as Marvel Cosmic Invasion is set to arrive in 2025. Exactly when hasn‚Äôt been announced yet, but there‚Äôs not much time left in the year so if it‚Äôs not getting delayed, the game is likely weeks away from launching on PS5, PS4, Xbox Series X/S, Xbox One, Switch 2, Switch, and PC.



https://kotaku.com/marvel-cosmic-invasion-steam-demo-pc-console-2025-coolest-looking-game-2000630663

item.title: The Sweet Side Of Pok√©mon Card Collecting That Scalpers Can‚Äôt Steal
item.content:encoded:
Although I‚Äôve sought out a handful of cards featuring my favorite monsters and characters, I generally only pay casual attention to the Pok√©mon Trading Card Game.  I grew up with a giant cardboard box of old cards under my bed, but as an adult, I can‚Äôt imagine putting in half the time or money I did into it as a kid. It just seems like it would be too much hassle, and that‚Äôs not to mention everything that happens around the game. When I do hear stories about the TCG, they‚Äôre usually stories of controversy. Images of people nearly destroying the Van Gogh Museum in order to get exclusive cards and merchandise to sell online, as well as grown-ass men fighting and camping out for cards outside of GameStops, are seared into my brain. This toxic, predatory side of Pok√©mon collecting has pushed a lot of people out of the space, as memories of excitement at finding your favorite card have been replaced by stories of scams and robberies. That was how it was for me until fairly recently, when I saw a video from Pok√©mon vendor @beard_dad_cardz having an extremely sweet interaction with a girl named Sophia at a card show.

As a fan of his streams, Sophia is excited to be at beard_dad_cardz‚Äôs booth, and his viewers are so excited about her excitement that they donate so she can get a card she likes. She says she‚Äôs a fan of Umbreon and Espeon, and after she finds a card of the dark-type Eeveelution she likes, beard_dad_cardz gives it to her for free. The moment went viral on multiple social media apps and has accumulated over 17.8 million views on TikTok alone.

A lot of Pok√©mon card vendors have taken up content creation as an extension of their business, and that means several of them livestream from card shows and capture moments like this regularly. You wouldn‚Äôt know it from the news, but there‚Äôs a lot of kindness, charity, and community in Pok√©mon cards that often gets drowned out by the worst bad actors. And as the stigma around the space has grown, creators and vendors like Chris Daywalt, the owner of HLD Cards and Collectibles, are trying to combat these notions by putting these moments of kindness on the internet, where people can see them.

‚ÄúThe rise of videos where you‚Äôre seeing people scalping Costco for cards or doing things like that, that‚Äôs going to happen any time you really shine a spotlight on something, especially something as big as Pok√©mon,‚Äù Daywalt told Kotaku. ‚ÄúWhen people start hearing money around it, those people are going to come out of the woodwork. They did the same thing to sneakers and to Supreme clothes, video cards, and PSIs, anything else that they feel like they can make a quick dollar on, but I think what makes Pok√©mon different is the 30 years of community that‚Äôs been built around it.‚Äù

Daywalt started HLD as a way to connect with his son Henry, whom the shop and channel are named after. Henry returned from a summer camp trip with his first set of Pok√©mon cards, which led to the father and son bonding over their collections. Daywalt says this ignited a passion in his son to start collecting and gave them a common interest, as Daywalt has been a lifelong TCG player, and grew up playing and trading with others.

‚ÄúI always used to say ‚ÄòI play Magic for the gathering,‚Äô and so I really knew the community part of it before I knew the reselling part of it,‚Äù Daywalt said.

What started as an opportunity for Daywalt to pass on his values around taking care of something and finding community quickly became a family business after his brother started making content out of their card show appearances, and his wife started handling other aspects of the business. Daywalt says he‚Äôs comfortable sharing this with his son because in his experience, the Pok√©mon community sticks to the messages of kindness the franchise touts. There are still some bad actors that try to take advantage of others, though, which is why Daywalt doesn‚Äôt do ‚Äútrade-ups,‚Äù or card exchanges in which the card the event attendee receives is of greater value than the one they part with, with adults, but will do them with kids.

Promoting those good moments is why a lot of vendors are branching out into content creation. Sure, it‚Äôs another extension of the business and also works as viral marketing, but the narrative of bad actors dominating the space has become so prevalent that long-time fans feel protective of Pok√©mon and the space they‚Äôve cultivated, and want to push back. Aaron Lee, one of the co-founders of Duckbird, grew up watching the Pok√©mon anime and has memories of waiting for new episodes to premiere on WBTV back in the day. As such, he‚Äôs been in the space long enough to have encountered people engaged in shady practices at card shows time and time again. However, he says a lot of these are less common at in-person events than one might think, and he especially experiences them less in his small North Carolina town.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll see people who you can tell are, like, obviously there to make a quick buck,‚Äù Lee told Kotaku. ‚ÄúThere will be even kids and adults who are obviously there trying to make money essentially; taking advantage of vendors and whatnot, and have their kids try to do a trade-up challenge to get them a better card. That‚Äôs a big one that I‚Äôve seen a lot, and that has come from a lot of influencers or YouTube content creators being able to do that. But if it‚Äôs, you know, someone who knows what they‚Äôre doing and[is] just trying to take advantage of people, that‚Äôs something that‚Äôs not so fun.‚Äù

For Lee and his partner, ‚ÄúDuck,‚Äù trying to make people feel welcome at card shows is important. Lee says that the pair tries to give free stuff to kids who show up, especially if they seem to be in the early days of their own collection journey.

‚ÄúWe kind of do like a rock-paper-scissors game, but we use Pok√© Balls with different types [of Pok√©mon], and we give them free packs if they win,‚Äù Lee says. ‚ÄúEven if they lose, we still give them free packs. We‚Äôll do coin flips with kids for free, and then even if they lose, we‚Äôll keep flipping until they win. So it‚Äôs stuff like that to just make sure that anybody who we feel like is new to the hobby or is genuinely passionate about collecting is able to have a positive experience when they go to a show or if they stop by our stream. Anything to just let them know, 

‚ÄòHey, there are still people out there who really enjoy the space and just want to grow the community in the right direction.‚Äô‚Äù

Welcome to Exp. Share, Kotaku ‚Äôs Pok√©mon column in which we dive deep to explore notable characters, urban legends, communities, and just plain weird quirks from throughout the Pok√©mon franchise.

Stories of vendors going out of their way to help kids get cards they‚Äôre looking for are pretty common at these events. Which is why, despite all the talk of big money in Pok√©mon these days, a lot of the biggest transactions are completely free.

‚ÄúI had people who were trying to find a card for a kid who‚Äôs looking for, like, a specific Pikachu card,‚Äù Lee said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôll tell their buddies and their buddies will tell their buddies, and then the whole show will be searching for a card and bringing it to the kid. Half the time, they give it to the kid for free. It really just depends on where you are and who you talk with, but I would say like 80 to 90 percent of vendors that you see in real life are kind. They go out of their way to help the kid out or help somebody out when they‚Äôre looking for something specific. I see a lot of kindness with vendors when, sometimes, you might be trying to trade a card in that might not necessarily move as well. A lot of times, vendors will match the card 100 percent and just give the kid what they want, just to help the kid out. That‚Äôs where it starts, when you‚Äôre a kid and you don‚Äôt really wanna look at this in a monetary way. You just want to collect cards. You can really tell if a kid is just trying to collect cards, you know, versus trying to make some money. And that‚Äôs what I like to see.‚Äù

Even with all these positive stories, piercing through all the constant reports of crimes and the viral moments showing scalpers acting a fool at major events can feel impossible. When I asked Daywalt what advice he‚Äôd give to someone trying to enter the space, he said the average collector and vendor is not going to be making thousands of dollars off these cards, and if you go into the hobby expecting that, you‚Äôre likely going to be disappointed.

‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs about the money, go trade stocks or work in finance,‚Äù Daywalt says. ‚ÄúWhat I always say to people is that the reason I don‚Äôt necessarily worry if the Pok√©mon market crashes tomorrow is because I‚Äôll look at it as an opportunity to go get all the cards I wanted. They have a value to me outside of what a TCG player says the market value is. Don‚Äôt put that pressure on something, you know, buy it because you like it and it‚Äôs something that brings you joy intrinsically, not extrinsically, because it could make you some money.‚Äù

Lee echoed the sentiment and said that some of the best cards are ones you won‚Äôt find selling for three or more figures, and if you aren‚Äôt interested in the art or community, there are easier ways to make money.

‚ÄúWe get tons of people coming up asking for particular Pok√©mon because they want to collect all of that Pok√©mon,‚Äù Lee says. ‚ÄúThen if it‚Äôs a less popular Pok√©mon like Dunsparce, then, you know, the cards aren‚Äôt gonna be as expensive, and it makes for a really fun time.‚Äù

Daywalt says that even after the time he‚Äôs put into buying, selling, and collecting, HLD isn‚Äôt paying his family‚Äôs bills, and that every dollar they make at these shows is going back into the business. While he admits he does get invested in predicting the market, he encourages people who are hoping to find the golden ticket in a Target booster pack to interrogate whether they‚Äôre in it for the right reasons.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of knowledge and a lot of really sharp people that are already in the space, and you‚Äôre not going to catch up to them tomorrow,‚Äù Daywalt says. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt care how many YouTube videos you watch or how many articles you read about it. If you want to get into this space, do it because it brings you joy. Do what you like, and make the money a secondary part of it if it‚Äôs important to you.‚Äù

After talking to vendors and seeing these kinds of wholesome interactions online, I still don‚Äôt know that Pok√©mon card collecting is for me. I have a collection of Raichu and Professor Turo cards on my shelf, and I think that‚Äôs probably enough. But after seeing the uptick in Pok√©mon card scams and content mills over the past few years, it was disheartening for a while to know a series that had brought me so much joy had become a symbol of predatory greed. At the very least, it‚Äôs comforting to know that some people are keeping the childlike wonder alive, and that they‚Äôre posting reminders of it online.



https://kotaku.com/pokemon-card-tcg-vendor-scalper-reseller-stream-shows-2000630658

item.title: Here Are 55 Games Coming Out In October 2025 And That‚Äôs Not Even All Of Them
item.content:encoded:
The spooky season is here and it‚Äôs packed with a terrifying number of new game releases. October is always a busy month but this year, it feels even more overwhelming than usual. Ghost of Yotei, the latest prestige open-world blockbuster from Sony, kicks things off this week while the team behind Shovel Knight wraps up the month with Mina the Hollower, their teeny, tiny, cozy homage to The Legend of Zelda: Link‚Äôs Awakening, debuting on Halloween. Trick or treat? Why not both!

In between, we‚Äôre getting the return of franchises with a lot to prove in Battlefield 6, Ninja Gaiden 4, and Vampire: The Masquerade ‚Äì Bloodlines 2, as well as other big sequels in Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A and The Outer Worlds 2. And don‚Äôt lose track of some of the top-wishlisted games on Steam coming in October, including Little Nightmares 3 and Arc Raiders. It‚Äôs felt like there are too many games for a while now. That‚Äôs a problem for the video game industry, but it offers a bounty of riches (and choice paralysis) for players this month.

Here are 55 games that are coming out in October 2025, and if you have a favorite upcoming release we missed, please share it in the comments.

Silly Polly Beast ‚Äì October 1

Platforms: PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X|S, PC
Developers: Anji Games
Publishers: Top Hat Studio
Genres: Adventure shooter

Publishers: Sony Interactive Entertainment
Genres: Open-world RPG adventure

item.title: The Internet Reacts To The Big Xbox Game Pass Price Hike
item.content:encoded:
Because raising prices for its console wasn‚Äôt enough, Xbox is also raising the price of its Xbox Game Pass subscription by a whopping 50 percent. The service, which gives people access to a large library of games for a monthly fee, has long been considered one of the best deals in gaming, especially for people who don‚Äôt want to buy dozens of games a year. You could theoretically just subscribe to Game Pass and have something new to play every month as games rotate in and out of its catalog. Well, today Microsoft announced it would be raising the price for the Ultimate tier from $20 to $30 a month. 

Along with the hefty price increase, the Ultimate tier is getting a lot of new games and perks, including the Ubisoft+ catalog and a Fortnite crew membership that gives you battle pass access and in-game currency every month. The other tiers are also going up in price, and will now include cloud gaming access and an expanded library. The PC Game Pass package, however, is going up from $12 to $16.50 with no new perks. Xbox frames this as a move toward flexibility and choice, but ultimately, Game Pass‚Äô claim to fame has always been its affordability, and now that its price is going up, the internet has feelings and jokes loaded up.

When I said i wanted the 360 era back, I didn't mean $360 a year.

‚Äî Daniel Ahmad (@ZhugeEX) October 1, 2025

From the people that brought you the $650 five-year-old Xbox Series X and the $1000 handheld gaming PC, comes‚Ä¶

$30 per month for Xbox Game Pass Ultimate! WHO‚ÄôS EXCITED??? /s

We went from $17 to $30 in 14 months, LOL.https://t.co/wcud6Grgly

‚Äî Ryan McCaffrey (@DMC_Ryan) October 1, 2025

https://t.co/AFYM0WtIlF pic.twitter.com/xtvsIz6BWG

‚Äî Puertorock77 (@Puertorock77_) September 30, 2025

there's still no annual subscription for Xbox Game Pass Ultimate. That means it's $360 a year, which is more than the Xbox Series S ($300) when it first launched ü§Ø

‚Äî Tom Warren (@tomwarren) October 1, 2025

The page to cancel Game Pass subscriptions is broken already, incredible https://t.co/qTWLQRWRBs pic.twitter.com/yZjRCMGosk

‚Äî Sam (@_sunday_rain_) October 1, 2025

Xbox Game Pass for 30 bucks? Are they insane? These price hikes on game pass, consoles, and games themselves are just pricing people OUT of gaming. No more "I'll give it a try" because of these prices. Absolutely wild to see how bad it's become, and prices will never go down.

‚Äî Kala Elizabeth (@kalaelizabeth) October 1, 2025

Xbox gamers realising they might actually have to buy games now pic.twitter.com/LqVlzxPpsa

‚Äî Yokio (@ItsNewYokio) October 1, 2025

The Xbox brand has gotten a lot more expensive in just the past few weeks, with the company raising the prices of Xbox Series X/S consoles and announcing that the most powerful version of the Rog Ally X handheld will cost a staggering $1000. If that price wasn‚Äôt high enough, scalpers are already trying to sell the thing for twice as much, despite the handheld being readily available elsewhere.



https://kotaku.com/xbox-game-pass-price-change-hike-reaction-ultimate-2000630654

item.title: Fallout 76‚Ä≤s Next Big Update Directly Connects To Amazon‚Äôs Hit TV Show
item.content:encoded:
Fallout 76 is going to Ohio, and waiting for players in the new region is none other than the Ghoul from the popular Fallout TV show on Amazon. This new expansion, which the devs claim is the biggest map expansion they‚Äôve done yet, is out later this year and also adds bounty hunting, new characters, fresh mutated creatures to kill, and more.

On October 1, Bethesda announced Fallout 76‚Ä≤s next big update, Burning Springs. This new update is set to arrive in early December for all platforms and adds a brand new region to the game‚Äôs map. The region is named Burning Springs, hence the name of the update. This area is set in Ohio, a location that we‚Äôve not seen much of in past Fallout media, giving the devs a bit of a blank slate to do whatever they want.  And according to the people making it, Burning Springs is directly inspired by Fallout 3 and Fallout: New Vegas.

Here‚Äôs a big update video from Bethesda going into more detail about the new region, what players can expect to find there, and more:

‚ÄúThe new region is terrifyingly beautiful and will feel very familiar to fans, drawing its main influences from Fallout 3 and New Vegas,‚Äù creative director Jon Rush told PC Gamer. ‚ÄúWe wanted it to remind folks of what they came to know and love in Fallout 3 and Fallout: New Vegas. And so when we set out to make this new region, the three pillars that we gave to the team were, ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs got to have desert, death claws and Raiders,‚Äô and to me, that captures the tone, the essence, and the danger of those games.‚Äù

While it‚Äôs neat that the new area is inspired by past Fallout games, the big news with Burning Springs is that it will directly connect to Amazon‚Äôs live-action Fallout TV show. As mentioned, the Ghoul from the show will be an NPC that people can talk to in Fallout 76‚Ä≤s new region. Located in Highway Town, he will hand out various repeatable bounties to players and is even voiced by Walton Goggins himself. Another example of the show and game syncing up: The free update is launching at around the same time season two of the show is set to premiere on Amazon Prime Video. And that‚Äôs not an accident.

‚ÄúBurning Springs is in total tonal tandem with Fallout season two, ‚ÄúRush told PC Gamer. ‚ÄúIt is poised to be our biggest update ever, and will coincide with the timing of the premiere of the Amazon Fallout series season two that‚Äôs coming this December.‚Äù

The new location in Fallout 76 will be added to the Western edge of the current map in a similar way to how the last world expansion, Skyline Valley, was added in 2024 to the bottom of the map. To access this new area, players will travel across the Point Pleasant Bridge, leaving Appalachia and entering Ohio.

Console players will have to wait until December to make that journey to Ohio to meet the Ghoul. But PC players willing to check out the update before launch will be able to start visiting the new region as early as tomorrow, October 2, via Fallout 76‚Äòs testing server. Bethesda also says full patch notes for the big update will arrive at that time, too.
